verses.text: Empty hopes and illusions lead those astray who lack understanding; dreams lift up fools.
verses.comment: This verse highlights the unreliability of dreams and visions apart from divine revelation. Such themes are echoed throughout Scripture—genuine guidance comes from God, not mere imagination or self-deception.

verses.text: As a man who grasps at shadows and chases the wind, so is he who puts his trust in dreams.
verses.comment: The text compares trusting in dreams to a futile effort, reminding readers to seek truth and wisdom from God’s revelation.

verses.text: What is seen in a dream is but a reflection, a face seen in a mirror.
verses.comment: Dreams are described as mere reflections, echoing Paul's later teaching about partial knowledge in this life. True clarity comes from God's direct revelation.

verses.text: From what is unclean, what can be made clean? From what is false, what truth can come?
verses.comment: The rhetorical questions stress the contrast between unclean or false sources and genuine purity or truth, connecting with Jesus’ teaching about good fruit coming from a good tree.

verses.text: Divinations, omens, and dreams are mere fantasies, and like visions of women in labor, they are without substance.
verses.comment: The text clearly condemns pagan practices and false prophecy. True prophetic visions, as found in Scripture, are distinguished from mere superstition.

verses.text: Unless they are sent from the Most High in a visitation, let not your mind dwell on them.
verses.comment: Authentic dreams and visions must come from God; otherwise, they are unreliable. This foreshadows how genuine prophecy in both Old and New Testaments is always initiated by God.

verses.text: For dreams have led many astray, and those who depend on them have failed.
verses.comment: Sirach warns against placing trust in dreams as sources of guidance, reflecting a broader biblical skepticism toward untested revelation (cf. Jer 23:25-32); theologically, this underscores reliance on God's established wisdom rather than speculative or deceptive experiences.

verses.text: Without law there is no wisdom, nor for those who act in ignorance of the commandments.
verses.comment: Wisdom flows from obedience to God's law. The importance of the commandments for spiritual growth is central—an anticipation of the law's fulfillment in Christ.

verses.text: An educated man acquires knowledge through travel; he who has great experience speaks with understanding.
verses.comment: Practical experience, especially traveling and learning from others, is valued. Wisdom is meant to be lived, not just learned theoretically.

verses.text: He who has never experienced hardship knows little, but he who has traveled is full of insight.
verses.comment: Suffering and new experiences are teachers; wisdom comes from engaging with the challenges of life.

verses.text: I have seen many things in my travels, and my understanding is greater than my words.
verses.comment: The author offers personal testimony about knowledge gained through experience, echoing Job’s humility before the mystery of God.

verses.text: Often I have been in danger of death, but I have been delivered because of these things.
verses.comment: Deliverance in danger is ascribed to faithfulness and wisdom, paralleling biblical stories of God saving His faithful ones.

verses.text: The spirit of those who fear the Lord will live, for their hope is in Him who saves.
verses.comment: The theme of hope and life for those who fear the Lord is central in both Old and New Testaments, and this verse points to the security found in God.

verses.text: Whoever fears the Lord will not be timid or afraid, for He is their hope.
verses.comment: Trusting in God wipes away fear—a message echoed in the Psalms and by Jesus himself in the Gospels.

verses.text: Blessed is the soul of the one who fears the Lord; on whom does he rely, and who supports him?
verses.comment: God Himself is the anchor and support of those who fear Him, reflecting the biblical beatitude of blessedness tied to true piety.

verses.text: The eyes of the Lord are upon those who love Him; He is their mighty shield and strong support, a shelter from scorching wind and a shade from midday heat, a guard against stumbling and a help against falling.
verses.comment: This elaborates on God’s personal care, using imagery common in the Psalms. God’s protection is comprehensive and intimate for those who love Him.

verses.text: He lifts up the soul and gives light to the eyes; He gives healing, life, and blessing.
verses.comment: Echoes of Christ's ministry appear here—Jesus gives sight, heals, and bestows spiritual life, fulfilling these promises.

verses.text: He who sacrifices from what was wrongfully gained, his offering is stained and not accepted.
verses.comment: The worth of sacrificial offerings lies in the justice and integrity behind them, not merely outward ritual—a consistent prophetic rebuke throughout Scripture.

verses.text: The Lord is not pleased with the offerings of the ungodly, and the multitude of sacrifices cannot atone for sins.
verses.comment: True repentance and righteousness are required; the Old Testament points ahead to ultimate atonement, which Christ fulfills sacramentally.

verses.text: He who offers a sacrifice from the goods of the poor is like one who kills a son in the presence of his father.
verses.comment: A powerful condemnation against hypocrisy and injustice. True sacrifice is marked by mercy, not exploitation.

verses.text: Bread gained by oppression is the life of the poor; he who takes it is a man of blood.
verses.comment: Social justice has deep roots in the Old Testament, anticipating Christ’s call for mercy and love of one’s neighbor.

verses.text: He who takes away his neighbor’s living kills him, and he who withholds a worker’s wages is a shedder of blood.
verses.comment: Unjust wages and the oppression of the vulnerable are grave sins in the eyes of God, a message reinforced by New Testament teaching.

verses.text: When one builds and another tears down, what do they gain but hard work?
verses.comment: Labor without unity or righteousness is empty. This also foreshadows Paul’s teaching on the unity of the body of Christ.

verses.text: When one prays and another curses, to whose voice will the Lord listen?
verses.comment: Contradictory actions undermine prayer; only the prayer offered with a pure heart is truly effective. The spiritual unity of prayer is foundational for the Church.

verses.text: If someone washed after touching a corpse and touched it again, what was the good of his washing?
verses.comment: This refers to ritual purity; true cleansing points to an inner reality, fully realized in Christ's sacrifice, which cleanses the conscience.

verses.text: So it is with a man who fasts for his sins, but goes and does them again: who will listen to his prayer, and what has he gained by humbling himself?
verses.comment: The validity of prayer and fasting depends on repentance that leads to change of heart and conduct. The persistent call to conversion and sincere contrition anticipates the theme of ongoing penance and reconciliation.

verses.text: He who devotes himself to fasting but is still unjust gains nothing from his fasting.
verses.comment: True fasting must be accompanied by acts of justice and mercy; outward signs must express inner transformation.

verses.text: The Most High detests the prayers of the unjust, and his mercy is far from the proud.
verses.comment: Humility and justice are required for God’s mercy. Prayer must proceed from a humble, contrite heart.

verses.text: The prayer of the humble pierces the clouds, and he will not be consoled until it reaches the Lord.
verses.comment: God’s special regard for humble prayer is seen in both Old and New Testaments; see Jesus’ parable of the tax collector in Luke.

verses.text: He will not desist until the Most High has regard for him, judges justly, and executes judgment.
verses.comment: Perseverance in prayer is encouraged. Christ himself affirms God’s responsiveness to those who cry out to Him day and night.

verses.text: And the Lord will not neglect the cry of the orphan, the widow, or the afflicted.
verses.comment: A repeated biblical promise of God’s special care for the vulnerable—a call to acts of mercy and justice, which remain integral to true worship.
